thread.title: City Council: Notorious eyesore property will become a park
thread.title_full: City Council: Notorious eyesore property will become a park | www.kirotv.com

author: kirotv.com
title: City Council: Notorious eyesore property will become a park
text:
The jagged ruins of blighted demolished houses in the shadow of Roosevelt High School will soon be transformed into a city park, according to a news release sent Monday by Mayor Ed Murray's office.
The idea of building a park at the vacant space along the NE 65th Street and 14th Avenue NE was first proposed by the mayor in March.
The property, owned by Hugh Sisley, was slated to be taken over by the city as partial payment for millions of dollars in fines Sisley was ordered to pay.
According to the release, when a land development group paid Sisley's fines, the city council had another option: use $2.9 million from the payment to acquire the vacant lots and build a park.
The mayor's release called the vote "a victory for neighbors who have been fighting blight and seeking a park for this community." Sam Parker, who lives next door to the lot, is one of several who are not celebrating the decision.
"I definitely think it's a missed opportunity," Parker said. "The neighborhood has quite a few parks surrounding it right now."
Parker said people in the Roosevelt neighborhood need affordable housing far more than a park.
"It's a feel-good," he said. "I think really what the discussion needs to be right now is not what feels good but what's going to be better for the city in the long run. I think affordable housing is a much better choice for that lot."
Murray has said he is willing to spend the rest of Sisley's fines to "provide assistance to tenants and manage nuisance properties that are a safety concern," the release stated. "We are also working closely with developers to ensure that additional affordable housing is part of a revitalized neighborhood.‚Äù
If the park is part of that revitalization as a spot for families to come together, Parker is left with questions:
"I think the question again is whose families? Which families can afford to live here?"
